Thanks for the suggestion re: the best practices link.

>I don't think it is necessary to put an "assertTrue(true);" in the
>catch block.

Probably not, but I find implicit idiomatic stuff always takes me a bit
longer to recognize.  If I see the method call "pass()" (or the uglier
assertTrue(true)) in the catch block, it's much clearer what the intent is.

-Jeff

-----Original Message-----
From: Mike Duffy
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Sent: 7/26/2001 1:58 AM
Subject: RE: [junit] Re: Errors and Exceptions

Jeff,

You should enter your comments into the Best Practices link created
by J. B. Rainsberger:

http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?JavaUnitBestPractices

I do almost exactly as you suggest.  When writing test methods, I
first write a test method for each exception in the throws cluase of
the method.  The only exception I create a catch block for is the
exception I am expecting for the specific test.  I use a trows
Excpetion in the test method and let the JUnit framework handle
anything unexpected that comes up.

I don't think it is necessary to put an "assertTrue(true);" in the
catch block.

Also, I use a unique naming convention for my test methods:

   test_##_nameofMethodBeingTested

// Test IllegalArgumentException is thrown when account number is
null.
public void test_00_isAccountAssigned() throws Exception {

    try {
       boolean assignedStatus =
accountWorker.isAccountAssigned(null);
       fail("IllegalArgumentException should have been thrown")

    } catch (IllegalArgumentException iae) {

        // Test Succeeds.
    } 
}

--- Jeff Langr <JLangr@...> wrote:
> I agree with Mr. Duffy and would like to add my thoughts.
> 
> Your test cases represent controlled contexts that you create.  You
> need to
> not only test all the "happy path" scenarios -- the ones where you
> expect no
> exceptions should be thrown -- but as well test the scenarios where
> you
> *expect* exceptions to be thrown. For example:
> 
> public void testTooManyPlayersOnField() {
> 	Field field = new Field();
> 	for (int i = 0; i < 11; i++)
> 		field.addPlayer();
> 	try {
> 		field.addPlayer();
> 		fail("should have thrown exception...");
> 	}
> 	catch (TooManyPlayersException e) {
> 		assertTrue(true);  // ugh.  "pass()" would be nice
> 	}
> }
> 
> For the happy path tests, I don't care what exception is thrown --
> it should
> never happen under normal circumstances. (If it does, something's
> seriously
> wrong anyway, and JUnit will still catch it.)  So I just declare
> that my
> test "throws Exception" where I have to (and use finally clauses
> when I need
> to).  That's the simplest thing that'll work in the light of Java's
> insistence that you deal with the potential for an exception.  
> 
> Using throws on test methods is fine as long as you document how to
> deal
> with all possible inappropriate things that *can* happen.  This
> documentation is through other tests that force and demonstrate
> these
> inappropriate things.  The nice part about this approach is that it
> pushes
> developers to learn how to treat exceptions early on.  Kind of like
> ensuring
> that you can actually restore from your backup tapes before you
> actually
> have to.  Most non-XP code I've seen does a poor job of organizing
> exceptions.  
> 
> Jeff L.
> Object Mentor, Inc.
